Fabian Pfortmüller
Grüezi, Swiss Entrepreneur & Community Builder, ZRH-NYC-BOM. Co-founder COMMUNITY, @Holstee, Sandbox, Incubaker. Love @NPR.
Mar 16

The 6 lifetime challenges I identified in my transition year as standing between me and a meaningful life

Or: unless I figure this out, my plan towards a meaningful life won’t be sustainable…

Originally, my transition last year had a pretty tangible question I was trying to answer: what do I want to focus on next?

While I was exploring that short-term quest (and thankfully found an answer), some bigger themes kept showing up. At first, these themes were very fuzzy, but as I dug beyond my superficial wants into my underlying motivations, passions, fears and dreams, 6 key challenges emerged.

Over time, I realized that these 6 challenges were not something I could “solve” in my transition, but that they would probably take me a lifetime to work on. And at the same time, I came to believe that if I wanted my transition work to have any real long-term impact, I didn’t really have a choice: I had to address them.

These are systemic issues with massive impact across all aspects of my life. And therefore, I can’t ignore them. Yes, I have a strong plan for the next 5+ years. But I’m convinced that these challenges will keep coming up, again and again, probably in the most uncomfortable moments, they will fuck with my well-being, and unless I work on them, my path towards a meaningful life will be mostly walking in a circle.

So here are my 6 lifetime challenges in short. I will explore some in separate, more in-depth posts in the weeks to come, but I wanted to get started somewhere:

1 — Making sure work doesn’t crowd out my core priorities in life

A significant element of my transition was to figure out what my personal definition of success is. And as part of that I realized quite quickly that society’s definition of success — productivity, money, fame, career — isn’t mine. My definition of a successful life, or in my own words a meaningful life, has elements of work in it: I want to do things things I genuinely care about. But at the same time there are other priorities that are equally, if not more, important to me: to spend a significant part of my energy and time investing into love and relationships. In the long-term this will bring so much joy and beauty to my life, and might have a higher payoff than doing work I love.

But realizing this is the easy part. Actually acting on this awareness is really, really hard. Everything around us reminds us of and promotes society’s definition of success. Work so easily crowds out everything else. Work is so good at staying top of mind, feeling important and urgent, while often it is not. So the challenge is to find ways to truly live according to my own priorities, but ideally without feeling marginalized. This will require serious reflection on ambition, fears, and self confidence. And it deserves dedicated and tailor-made tools, structures, habits and processes.

2 — Living in the present moment

This is the most abstract, and yet most fundamental one. No matter what I do in life, no matter how meaningful things I decide to do, no matter if I get to focus on relationships, unless I learn to be fully present, to be fully there, all these precious years of living will be a waste of time. And I have a far way to go, I live in my thoughts, in reflections of the past and dream of the future so much more than in the present moment. So what’s my path to live in the now?

3 — Addressing and mastering my core fear of “not being enough”

I realized last year how crucially important regular and deep reflection on my fears is for my personal growth and sustained well-being. I found many fears, but I have come to believe that at the very core they all boil down to one: the fear that I am not good enough. That fear expresses itself in almost all aspects of my life: that I constantly want more (even though I have enough), that I’m constantly trying to be better (even though I am good enough), that I think I should try harder (even though I try hard enough), and that I expect more from other people (even though they are enough). And then it manifests in the world in the form of ego, misguided ambition, fear of commitment, fear of failure, anger, resentment. I’m convinced that a meaningful life is based on the concept of feeling “enough”, and overcoming this fear will be essential to walk that path.

4 — The courage to live & express my full truth

When we are children, expressing our truth is easy and straightforward. That’s all we have. But as we grow older, we become constrained, we develop a gap between the truth inside of us and what we express and how we act in the outside world. And at some point, we lose touch with our real, inner truth. Last year, I not only realized the importance of reconnecting with my truth. I also found that the hardest part isn’t looking for the truth, the hardest part is to develop the courage to actually take my own truth seriously, accept it for what it is, express it and ultimately live it.

5 — Accepting that self compassion isn’t easy, but crucial to learn

I always felt this was such an obvious one: that I should treat myself well first, because if I don’t treat myself kindly, who will? Yet I have come to realize last year, that while, in theory, this makes sense, I don’t actually live according to that mindset. In fact, that parts of me actively resists it. And, furthermore, I have no idea how to actually do it and everything from my own ego, my ambition and societies expectations take me away from that. So how do I learn self compassion and start applying it?

6 — Accepting whatever happens in life

Last year I applied to a program at Singularity University and in my own arrogance I was so sure that I would get in. But then reality hit and I got rejected. They didn’t even call me to the first round of interviews. First I tried to play it down, but then all the emotions of anger, disappointment and fear of failure hit me. And while the new reality was pretty clear, I was trying to fight it as hard as I could. This and several other unexpected setbacks last year taught me an important lesson: that shit will keep happening in life. But that I have a choice of how I react to it: that I can either spend a lot of energy fighting it, rejecting it, ignoring it, or I can embrace it and use that energy to build on top of it.

How I reflect on the 6 challenges and what they have in common

  • They are important, but they do not feel urgent. That’s a massive problem. So unless I make them a priority and create the right habits and structures for them, they will never get solved.
  • They are relatively simple intellectual concepts, easily understood, but very hard to implement.
  • Many of these topics are usually described in language that I don’t relate to. Esoteric language is used to talk about topics such as presence, truth, self compassion. I don’t connect with that language , so I need to find my own.
  • All of them are connected and strongly overlap. The fear of not being enough holds me from fully living my truth, and the lack of courage to live my truth is what allows work to crowd out my real priorities in life. And if I truly feel enough, self compassion should come more easily, right?
  • I’m sure for someone else, the same topics might divide into 10 challenges, or 4. I think it’s less important to have the “right” challenges identified and find all of them. But I think it’s important to name them, describe them and then work towards solving them. I’m sure I will find other challenges along the way and they will evolve as life progresses.

— —

Hi, I’m Fabian, a serial entrepreneur living between NYC, Mumbai and Zurich. Last year, I went through a transition: I left my last startup with no idea what would come next, but with the intention of not just stumbling into the next thing, but consciously figure it out. My year of transition became one of the most powerful moments of my life, I learned a ton and I did figure out what I wanted to do next.

This blog is my attempt to capture what I have learned during my last year of transition, to become better at “transitioning” and share it with my friends. You’ll find more stories and insights at www.transitionnotes.com. If you want to be notified of new transition related posts, sign up here. If you’re in transition or interested in learning more about transitioning, join our Facebook group where we share ideas and best practice. And if you have any thoughts or feedback, please email me pforti at gmail or message me on Twitter— thank you and I hope your own transitions are going well!
